title: Why Do I Need a Calcium Blood Test?
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: A calcium blood test can find out whether you have too much or too little of this key mineral in your bloodstream. It’s often part of a routine screening.
This test helps screen for and diagnose diseases that affect your bones, heart , muscles, nerves, kidneys , and other organs.
Calcium is the most plentiful mineral in your body. Your body uses it to:
Almost all of your body's calcium is stored in your bones. A very small amount -- about 1% -- is in your blood. Calcium in your blood comes in two forms:
There are two types of blood calcium tests:
bullets: Free calcium is not attached to anything else in your blood.
Bound calcium is attached to a protein called albumin or other substances in your blood.
A total calcium test measures both free and bound calcium. It's the type of blood calcium test doctors order most often.
An ionized calcium test measures only free calcium.

sections.heading: When Would I Get This Test?
content: Your doctor might do a calcium blood test during a regular health exam. Your doctor might order a basic metabolic panel (BMP) or a comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) which includes a test for calcium along with other substances.
You might get a calcium blood test if you have a disease that can affect your levels of this mineral, such as:
You might also get this test if you have an EKG heart test that has certain abnormalities.
This test can check how well your body is reacting to treatments for some of these conditions. And, it can be used to monitor the side effects of medicines you take.
bullets: Cancer of the breast , lung , kidney , head, and neck, or multiple myeloma
Pancreatitis , which is inflammation of the pancreas
Parathyroid disease, in which glands in your neck are either too active or not active enough, causing unhealthy levels of calcium in your blood
Problem absorbing nutrients from food in your intestines

sections.heading: How Do I Prepare?
content: Tell your doctor about all the medicines you take -- even medications you bought over the counter (without a prescription). Some medications can affect the results of your calcium blood test.

sections.heading: What Happens During the Test?
content: A lab tech will take a sample of blood from a vein in your arm. You might feel a pinch where the needle goes in. They’ll cover the site with a bandage.
Your arm may be a little sore or bruised where the blood was drawn. Some people become lightheaded for a few moments.
